h i g h l i g h t s
Four different silica-based materials were evaluated. Hydration, rheology, porous structure, and compression strength were studied. The use of nano-silica and silica fume was responsible for refinement of pores. Rheological properties were found to improve with addition of the different silicas.

Keywords: High-energy milling Portland cement hydration Mineral addition Cement pastes Microstructure
a b s t r a c t
This work compares the influence of nano-silica with three different silica-based materials (quartz, ultrafine quartz, and silica fume) on hydration, rheology, porous structure, and compression strength in cement pastes with 2.5% cement replacement. Results of calorimetry showed that the inclusion of the silica fume and of nano-silica resulted in an acceleration of hydration of the pastes. In regard to quartz, no change in comparison to the reference was observed until a median particle size of 0.6 mm was reached. The use of nano-silica and silica fume was responsible for refinement of the porous structure and for an increase in compressive strength of the paste in comparison to the reference, caused by their role on heterogeneous nucleation and pozzolanic reactivity. On the other hand, quartz and ultrafine quartz did not have a marked effect on these properties. The rheological properties were also found to improve with addition of the different silicas.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The use of both chemically active or inert mineral admixtures to cement-basedmaterials has grown during the last few decades due to their technical advantages (increase in strength and durability) and environmental (associated to the reduction in cement
consumption). One example of this application is silica fume, one of the mineral additions that are most widely used in construction and building since the 1970s and that remains the focus of research due to its high reactivity [1–4].
In recent years, mineral additions that are either inert or that have low reactivity, besides very reduced sizes, have been capturing special attention due to a growing demand of new mineral additives, given the scarcity of traditional mineral admixtures, e.g. fly ash and blast furnace slag, in some countries. For instance, recent studies demonstrated the increase in pozzolanic activity of sugarcane bagasse ash with high levels of contamination of quartz
due to reduction in size of its particles during grinding [5–6]. In another work, the incorporation of quartz particles (10–75%) in mortars promoted an increase in the degree of hydration in comparison to the reference mortar [7].
Besides these effects, the reduction in particle size by grinding can boost the effect of heterogeneous nucleation, due to the inclusion of new nucleation sites for deposition of the hydrated products [8–12]. Grinding can also be responsible for promoting partial amorphization and significant increase in specific surface area [5–6,13–18]. Indeed, mechanical size reduction has been widely used to render chemical reactivity to inert silica-based materials, especially in the application of high-energy milling, which breaks the particles and generates fine, ultrafine and nanometer-sized particles [17,19–23].
The colloidal nano-silica is composed of amorphous particles, with sizes that vary from 1 to 500 nm, which results in unique physical and chemical properties when compared to admixtures made up of coarser particles [24]. Byung-Wan et al. [25] observed that the use of colloidal silica improves the microstructure of both mortars and concrete. The influence of addition of nano-silica in cement pastes was also investigated by Singh et al. [26] and in pastes for oil drillings by Balza et al. [27], Santra et al. [28], and Pang et al. [29]. It was found that nano-silica has higher pozzolanic reactivity than silica fume [25,30,31]. However, Hou et al. [32] demonstrated that the paste containing silica fume presented higher degree of hydration of the cement in comparison to nanosilica, both replacing cement at 5% in weight. Similar results were found by Thomas et al. [33].
Materials in the range of nano and microparticles with this composition have been found to have different effects on the structure and on the performance of cement-based materials [34]. In this context, the present work investigates the influence of silicas of different natures and sizes on the hydration and on the physical andmechanical response of cement pastes on the basis of rheology, isothermal calorimetry, intrusion mercury porosimetry and compressive strength. A recognizably reactive nano-silica was used as a model reactive material.

sections.heading: 2.1. Paste constituents
sections.text:
Three different commercially available silica samples were initially used: quartz (Mineração Jundu, Brazil) with D50 of 19.3 mm and BET specific surface area (SSA) of 1636 m2/kg; silica fume (Silmix, Brazil) with D50 of 0.2 mm and SSA of 14,366 m2/kg; and colloidal nano-silica (Cembinder W50, Brazil) with D50 of 4 nm and SSA of 188,000 m2/kg. These silica samples were designated as QZ1 (quartz), SF (silica fume), and NS (nano-silica). From the QZ1, another quartz sample (designated as QZ2) was obtained by high-energy wet grinding. This procedure was performed by using the Szvegari attrition mill, model 1-S (Union Process, Inc., U.S.A.) with 50% filling and 2% sodium hexametaphosphate (Proquimios, Brazil) solution as dispersant (46.4 kg/t solid-solution mass ratio). The total grinding time was 10 h, being 2 h with silicon nitride balls (5 mm diameter) as grinding media, and Zirconox, a ceria-stabilized zirconia (0.5–1.0 mm diameter), during the remainder of the time. QZ1 and SF were used in solid state and QZ2 and NS as slurry with solids content in weight of 15 and 22%, respectively.
Fig. 1 shows the particle size distribution of different silica samples from laser diffraction analyses (Malvern Mastersizer 2000, U.K.). Deionized water was used as a dispersant for QZ1 and NS. Sodium hexametaphosphate (0.5%) and sodium polyacrylate (0.5%) solutions were used for dispersing QZ2 and SF, respectively, in the particle size analyzes. X-ray diffraction patterns (Bruker D4 Endeauver, Germany) of three original silica samples are displayed in Fig. 2. Obviously, quartz was identified in QZ1, and SF and NS were completely amorphous. Table 1 shows the oxide composition and main physical characteristics of silica samples, where it is possible to note that all samples presented SiO2 content higher than 93%. Moreover, the QZ2 also contained minor quantities of impurities, e.g. P2O5, Na2O, and ZrO2, indicating the presence of the grinding dispersant and ZrO2 worn from the grinding media. A 2.5% total carbon content of silica fume was quantified by using a Leco SC 632 (U.S. A.) analyzer and is also given in Table 2. The density of dry nanosilica was 2524 kg/ m3, while the suspension (15% in weight of SiO2) presented a density of 1100 kg/m3 (provided by the manufacturer).
Brazilian Class G Portland cement [35] (Holcim), which is an ordinary Portland cement (without mineral addition) used in oil well cementing operations, polycarboxylate-based superplasticizer with 31.6% solid content (Basf Glenium 51, Brazil), and deionized water were used during this study. Particle size distribution and oxide composition of cement are displayed in Fig. 1 and Table 1, respectively. Table 1 also shows some important characteristic of the Class G cement.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation and characterization of cement-based pastes
sections.text:
A reference paste (P-REF) with no mineral addition, and other four pastes with each silica replacing 2.5% of the cement mass (named P-QZ1, P-QZ2, P-SF, and P-NS) were designed with a water-solid ratio of 0.4. The superplasticizer was used at dosages of 0.021% (P-REF), 0.018% (P-QZ1), 0.005%, (P-QZ2), 0.027% (P-SF), and 0.573% (P-NS) considering a fixed spread diameter (ranging from 100 to 120 mm) from Kantro minislump tests [36] – truncated cone with 60 mm height, 20 mm diameter at the top, and 40 mm diameter at the bottom. The similar superplasticizer contents of P-SF and P-QZ1 in relation to that used in P-REF were due to the low cement replacement level (2.5%), which is typical for pastes containing nanosilica [37–39]. The lowest superplasticizer content of P-QZ2 could be justified by the use of sodium hexametaphosphate solution as dispersant during grinding.
The rate of hydration heat was recorded for a period of up to 7 days using a TAM Air (TA Instruments, U.S.A.) isothermal calorimeter at 23 C. Approximately 6 g of each paste was introduced in glass ampoules and measurements of heat flow were recorded every 1 min. For this test, the pastes were mixed by adding solid materials to water and superplasticizer in a 100 ml beaker and stirring with a spatula by hand for 1.5 min. For other tests, the pastes were mixed in a high-shear blender type mixer (Chandler 30360, U.S.A.) with bottom driven blades for 10 min at
n.a.: not available.
2970 rpm. For P-NS, the nano-silica was previously dispersed in water and superplasticizer for a 3-min additional time at 2970 rpm due to the high water demand of NS.
Before the rheological tests, all pastes were homogenized in an atmospheric consistometer (Chandler Engineering, Model 1200, U.S.A.) for 20 min at 27 C. Rheological parameters were obtained by using a Chandler 3506 rotational rheometer with coaxial concentric cylinders geometry (bob and rotor). The height of bob is 38 mm and the diameters of rotor and bob are 18.42 and 17.25 mm, respectively, providing a shear gap size of 1.17 mm. The flow curve was determined with descending speeds from 300 to 3 rpm for 12.5 min. Tests were performed in triplicate for each paste. The rheological data were fitted using the Bingham plastic model (Eq. (1)), where the paste presents a linear shear stress-shear rate behavior after an initial shear stress threshold has been reached.
s ¼ s0 þ l _c ð1Þ
where s is the shear stress, s0 is the yield stress, l is the plastic viscosity, and c is the shear rate. The plastic viscosity and yield stress were estimated from the slope of the line and threshold stress, respectively.
Pore size distribution of pastes was measured by mercury intrusion porosimetry (MIP) using a Micromeritics AutoPore IV (U.S.A.) with a maximum 275 MPa injection pressure. Spherical pores, surface tension of mercury of 480 dyn/cm, and contact angle of 117 were assumed. The samples of approximately 1 cm3 were cut out using a diamond cutter from the mid-portion of cylinders with 50 mm diameter and 100 mm height after 7 days of curing at 40 C. The mercury porosity is defined as the ratio between the total injected mercury volume and the total volume of the sample.
Compressive strength tests were performed in cylindrical (50 mm diameter and 100 mm height) specimens at 8 h, 1, 7, and 28 days of curing in lime-saturated water at 40 C. Five specimens were tested in each age by using a Shimadzu UH-F 1000 kN (Japan) servohydraulic machine operating at a 0.1-mm/min displacement rate. Two diametrically opposed linear variation displacement transducers were used to measure the median axial displacement over a gage length of 50 mm at mid-height of the specimen. Then, the modulus of elasticity was calculated considering the linearity of the axial stress-specific strain curve according to ASTM C469/ C469 M-14 [40]. Comparisons of compressive strength and modulus data were compared by statistical analysis of variance and Tukey’s multiple range test [41].

sections.heading: 3.1. Isothermal calorimetry
sections.text:
The evolution of the flow of heat in the different pastes at 23 C is indicated in Fig. 3a. In general, all pastes presented the same
behavior after 3 days of hydration with four distinct periods, i.e. cement wetting (stage not discussed in this work), induction, acceleration, and deceleration. P-QZ1 presented similar behavior to P-REF, confirming the inert nature of QZ1, which contains coarse particles in comparison to Portland cement. However, after ultrafine grinding, QZ2 was responsible for an increase in the induction period in 2.7 h in comparison to P-REF. This effect is likely to be associated to the presence of sodium hexametaphosphate, which was used as dispersant during the ultrafine grinding of the material. Phosphate ions form insoluble salts with calcium, thus reducing the concentration of Ca2+ in solution. Besides that, these insoluble salts can be formed in the surface of cement grains, creating a barrier for the development of the hydration reaction [42]. Because of this, the maximum flow of heat of P-QZ2 was reached only after 15.9 h, whereas for P-REF this was reached after 10.4 h of hydration. Although sodium hexametaphosphate caused an expressive delay in hydration, its use was supported because it allowed reaching the same level of dispersion as the other methods not only during grinding, but also when the suspension was left standing for days, waiting for use.
The incorporation of SF reduced in 25 min the induction period in comparison to P-REF, being responsible for a significant acceleration in the beginning of the reactions (Fig. 3a). The maximum flow of heat was reached after 10 h, so that no significant difference in respect to P-REF was observed. It is important to stress that the reduced level of replacement used (2.5%) was insufficient to promote large acceleration in hydration reactions, which contrasts to results from Korpa et al. [31], Rahhal et al. [44], and Thomas et al. [33], who used replacements varying from 10 to 25%.
The introduction of nano-silica resulted in a significant increase in reaction rates, after a period of induction that was similar to the one observed for the other pastes, with exception of P-QZ2, as is evident in Fig. 3a. In this case the maximum flow of heat was reached after 8.7 h of the mixing. The increase in the heat of hydration in early ages is mainly associated to hydration of C3S. This increase in the acceleration may be attributed to the effect of nucleation of the nano-silica particles, as previously observed by
Land and Stephan [12], and Thomas et al. [33]. In general, the effect of nucleation is associated to the reduction in the induction period, which was not observed for P-NS probably due to the high dosage of superplasticizer. Several authors have also detected this delay effect of superplasticizers in different mixtures at early ages [10,25,45]. It is important to stress that the ‘‘shoulder” relative to the tricalcium aluminate (C3A) hydration was more pronounced for mixtures P-QZ2 and P-NS due to the effect of the heterogeneous nucleation. P-QZ1 and P-SF did not present significant changes in comparison to P-REF.
Fig. 3b presents the cumulative heat curves during the seven first days of hydration for all pastes. A significant increase in the heat liberated in the pastes with mineral addition was observed, which indicated the increase in the formation of hydrated phases in respect to the amount of cement. For instance, for P-NS, an increase in about 10% in comparison to P-REF was observed at seven days. After one day of hydration, the accumulated heat of P-QZ2 exceeded that generated by P-REF. This confirms the increase in hydration promoted by the ultrafine quartz since this sample caused a significant delay of the acceleration period. It is worth noting that amorphous compounds were not observed in the quantitative X-ray diffraction analyses by Rietveld method of both QZ1 and QZ2, indicating that ultrafine grinding did not promote amorphization of quartz as was previously reported in some studies [17,43]. X-ray diffraction scan of QZ2 is shown in Fig. 2.

sections.heading: 3.2. Rheology
sections.text:
Fig. 4 presents the results of shear stress versus shear rate of the pastes. Results indicated that the Bingham model could properly describe the data. From the flow curves of P-REF and P-QZ1 it was evident that the presence of QZ1 reduced the yield stress, in spite of the small level of replacement used. The pastes P-SF and P-QZ2 presented higher shear stresses than the reference paste at comparable shear stresses, owing to the higher specific surface area of the mineral additives (QZ2 and SF) which retained part of the water of the mixture, decreasing the availability of water that facilitates rolling between the particles, so that the distance between them becomes smaller, which results in larger values of yield stresses due to increased surface friction. This behavior was even more pronounced when NS was incorporated (P-NS). Although this paste presented higher values of shear stresses, it was also observed that it presented lower yield stress than pastes P-QZ2 and P-SF. This can be explained by the use of the higher dosage of superplasticizer in P-NS. It is anticipated that if superplasticizer is not used this increase in stress would be even greater.
Table 2 presents the values of plastic viscosity (l) and yield stress (s0) for the pastes and their corresponding coefficients of variation. The results indicate that the mixtures P-QZ1, P-QZ2, and P-SF did not present significant differences in plastic viscosities in comparison to P-REF, when different dosages of superplasticizer are used to reach the specified consistency. The use of NS resulted in an increase in plastic viscosity of approximately 80% in comparison to P-REF, being the rheological parameter that varied the most.
The yield stress of pastes P-QZ2, P-SF, and P-NS was higher than the value observed in the reference paste (34.8 Pa), with a maximum value of 41.9 Pa found for P-SF. It allows concluding that the use of finer materials promoted an increase in this property for mixtures P-QZ2, P-SF, and P-NS (13.4%, 20.6%, and 8.0%, respectively) in relation to P-REF. However, in spite of the fact that P-NS was formulated with the finest mineral additive, it presented the smallest increase in the yield stress amongst pastes P-SF and PQZ2. This may have been due to the high superplasticizer dosage required to reach the desired consistency in this case. In the case of P-QZ1, which is composed of micron-sized particles, a reduction occurred in comparison to the other pastes.

sections.heading: 3.3. Pore size distributions
sections.text:
According to the classification proposed by Mindess et al. [46], pores sized over 10 mm are defined as air voids. Pores sized from
50 nm to 10 mm are defined as large capillary pores. Pores sized from 10 to 50 nm are defined as medium capillary pores, whereas pores sized from 2.5 to 10 nm are defined as small capillary (gel) pores. The cumulative pore size distribution curves of the pastes are shown in Fig. 5a. It is observed that the pastes presented larger proportion of their pore volume (ɸ) in the intermediate capillary size range (10 < ɸ 50 nm) and a small proportion of pores larger than 50 nm. The paste P-QZ1, which contained the crystalline mineral admixture, did not present nearly any difference in porosity in comparison to P-REF. In the case of paste P-QZ2, it was observed that the QZ2 produced by high-energy milling increased the volume of pores, with small capillaries in 3.2% and larger sized capillaries in 4%, whereas the medium-sized capillaries were equivalent to those of P-REF. For the P-SF, a greater refinement in the porous structure was observed, with the increase in volume of small capillaries in 23% and a reduction in the volume of medium (2%) and large sized capillaries (22%) in comparison to P-REF. In the utilization of pastes containing nanoparticles (P-NS) a 130% increase in the volume of small capillaries (2.5 < ɸ 10 nm), a reduction in 26% in the volume of medium-sized capillaries and a 50% increase in the volume of large capillaries was found in comparison to the reference (P-REF). These results are justified by the nucleation effect and the high chemical reactivity of nanosillica [12]. Therefore, P-NS presented a more refined porous network than P-SF
and, therefore, the reduction in particle size of the mineral additives resulted in a refinement of the porous structure and, thus, in the reduction in the threshold pore size. Indeed, for pastes PQZ2, P-SF and P-NS the threshold pore sizes were 34.6 nm, 27.6 nm, and 22.0 nm, respectively, in comparison to the P-REF (43.3 nm), whereas the use of QZ1 did not modify the threshold pore size.
The critical pore sizes of pastes were estimated from the differential distribution curve [47], which is illustrated in Fig. 5b. It is observed that the differential curves of the pastes exhibited a monomodal pore size distribution, fromwhich a single critical pore size may be identified. It is also observed that the critical pore sizes in P-NS and P-SF were 11.2 and 17.6 nm, respectively, while this value for P-REF is 27.6 nm. This indicates that the connected porous networks in pastes with P-NS and P-SF are composed mainly of pores of smaller sizes than those found in P-REF.
3.4. Uniaxial compression and Young0s modulus
The evolution of the compressive strength for curing times of 8 h, 1, 7, and 28 days is presented in Fig. 6. After 8 h of curing, statistical analyzes of the strength data showed that quartz (P-QZ1) did not promote any significant change in this measure in comparison the reference paste (P-REF). The inert character of the quartz particles, in regard to their pozzolanic activity, and the small level of replacement of cement explain why no change was observed, confirming observations made on the basis of isothermal calorimetry. Paste P-QZ2, on the other hand, presented a significant reduction in strength, in comparison to the reference paste. This reduction was due to the delay during the first day of hydration, as observed in the isothermal calorimetry tests. In contrast to that, Paste P-SF showed a 27% increase in strength in comparison to PREF, confirming the acceleration of the hydration reactions made possible by the silica fume during the first few hours of hydration. This effect was even more evident for nano-silica, since P-NS presented 116% higher strength than the reference paste (P-REF).
For 1 day of curing, no changes in compressive strength were observed for pastes P-QZ1 and P-QZ2 in comparison to the reference paste (P-REF). At this stage of curing, the delay effect observed for 8 h of curing was no longer evident for P-QZ2, as observed in accumulated released heat (Fig. 3-b). Pastes P-SF and P-NS presented 42% and 67% higher strength than P-REF, respectively. A similar behavior was observed after 7 days of curing. In this age
it is important to stress that an increase in compressive strength was presented by P-SF, which was only 7% lower than the value found for P-NS.
After 28 days of curing, pastes P-QZ1 and P-QZ2 did not present significant differences in compressive strength in comparison to PREF. Nevertheless, P-QZ2 presented a significant increase (13%) in comparison to P-QZ1, which demonstrated the benefit of reducing the particle size of quartz to increase the compressive strength, even at such small levels of cement replacement. Similar results were reported by Moosberg-Bustnes et al. [48]. It is important to stress that the delay in hydration promoted by QZ2 did not have a deleterious effect on the long-term mechanical response of the respective paste.
The strengths of the P-SF and P-NS pastes at 28 days of curing did not present statistically significant differences, presenting approximately 25% higher strength than the reference paste (PREF). Qing et al. [37] also observed that the strength of silica fume and nano-silica pastes became similar after 28 days of curing, when incorporated 3% and 5% (in mass of cement) of these types of silica in pastes.
Fig. 7 presents typical axial stress versus specific strain curves for the pastes after 28 days of curing. In the curves for P-NS, PQZ1, and P-SF it is evident that rupture occurred before stabilization of loading, which suggests that the strengths could be higher than registered, as result of some concentration of stresses on the top of the sample test pieces. It can be noted in Fig. 7 that while the compressive strength is relatively similar for P-REF and P-QZ2, their deformations at fracture are significantly different, demonstrating an obvious toughening effect due to QZ2 (also observed for other tested specimens), to which the dispersing agent (sodium hexametaphosphate) may have contributed. This positive synergic effect between the dispersing agent and the reduced particle size of quartz may have been responsible for this desirable improved mechanical response observed. Regarding the elastic modulus, Table 3 shows that incorporation of QZ1, QZ2, SF, and NS, with mean particle sizes of 19.3 mm, 0.6 mm, 0.2 mm, and 5 nm, respectively, in the pastes did not result in significant differences.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
Grinding of quartz (QZ2) in an attrition mill did not result in amorphization of the crystalline phases, but in a significant increase in specific surface area. The different particle sizes and the different natures of the materials studied, some with high pozzolanic activity and others inert, resulted in widely different kinetics of cement hydration.
The use of admixtures with progressively finer sizes resulted in a reduction in the workability of the cement pastes, in particular in the cases of nano-silica and silica fume. As such, the use of superplasticizer at a dosage of 0.57% in P-NS was necessary, but was responsible for a delay in hydration during the first hours of curing.
The use of nano-silica and silica fume promoted an improvement in the mechanical response of the pastes after hardening. Such improved performance may be attributed to the accelerated heterogeneous nucleation, to the improved packing of these mixtures and to the reactivity of the particles in these sizes. As such, the performance of these pastes was enhanced in comparison to pastes containing quartz particles of median sizes D50 equal to 0.6 mm (QZ2) and 19.3 mm (QZ1). The response of pastes containing amorphous silica (SF and NS) after seven days of curing was relatively similar.
Partial replacement of cement in 2.5% by inert silica (QZ1) and ultrafinely ground silica (QZ2) did not present differences in the mechanical properties at either 1, 7 or 28 days of curing. In the case of QZ1 this constancy was explained by the small amount of silica replacing cement and its relatively coarse size, thus limiting the role of the filler effect. The benefit associated to the ground silica (QZ2) that was expected did not appear, due to the deleterious phosphate-based dispersant introduced during grinding. Nevertheless, an increase of deformation at fracture in the paste containing QZ2 shows the appearance of a toughening effect, which is beneficial. A significant refinement of the porous structure was observed for pastes P-SF and P-NS in comparison to the reference paste (PREF). The modification of the hydration of the cement pastes was a direct result of the use of the admixtures.
Further microstructural analyses (e.g., SEM and 29Si MAS NMR) are needed to elucidate the effect of different types of silica on the hydration mechanisms and the structure of hydrates.
